content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Jessica Schroer: I was born in Naperville, Illinois, and grew up in a small, tight-knit community in the East North Central region. My parents were both hardworking people—my father worked as a mechanic, and my mother was a part-time nurse and full-time homemaker. We lived in a modest home, but it was always filled with love and laughter. I was the oldest of two siblings, and I remember helping my mother with chores around the house while my younger brother played outside. I always knew I wanted to go to college, so I worked hard in school, even though I didn't have a lot of resources. I received a scholarship to a local university, where I studied business administration. I graduated with a bachelor's degree and landed a job in marketing shortly after. I met my husband, Mark, during a company event, and we got married a few years later. Life has been full of ups and downs, but I've always tried to stay grounded in my faith and values. Recently, I've been taking some time off work due to a temporary illness, which has given me a chance to reflect on everything I've accomplished so far and what I still hope to achieve.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Jessica Schroer: One of the most defining moments in my life was when I decided to pursue a college education. I had always known I wanted to go to college, but the reality of it was daunting. My parents didn't have a lot of money, and I was the first in my family to consider higher education. I remember sitting at the kitchen table with my mother, who had just finished her associate's degree, and she looked at me and said, 'If you want it, you have to work for it.' That moment stuck with me. I took on part-time jobs during high school, saved every penny I could, and applied for scholarships. I was accepted to a local university on a partial scholarship, and I was determined to make the most of it. There were times when I felt overwhelmed, especially when I saw my friends from high school who had taken different paths—some went straight into the workforce, others joined the military. But I knew that for me, college was the path that would give me the most opportunities. Looking back, I don't think I would have chosen any other path. It shaped who I am today, gave me the confidence to pursue my career, and ultimately led me to meet my husband. It wasn't an easy decision, but it was the right one for me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Jessica Schroer: I think it was a conscious choice, but one that felt almost inevitable. I remember feeling a mix of fear and excitement when I got that acceptance letter. It wasn't just about the education—it was about proving to myself and my family that I could do something bigger than what we had always known. I didn't just choose college; I chose to believe in a future that felt out of reach. That belief carried me through late nights in the library, through the stress of exams, and even through the moments when I doubted if I was good enough. I think, in a way, I didn't have much of a choice because I had already made up my mind. But I also know that if I hadn't made that decision, I wouldn't be the person I am today—someone who values hard work, opportunity, and the power of education.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Jessica Schroer: Absolutely. I think a lot of people don't realize how much support is out there, especially for someone like me who was the first in my family to go to college. My high school counselor was incredibly supportive, and she helped me apply for scholarships I didn't even know existed. There was also a local community organization that offered mentorship programs for students from similar backgrounds. I remember one mentor in particular, Mrs. Thompson, who took me under her wing and encouraged me to think bigger than just my small town. She even helped me with my college essays and gave me confidence when I was struggling with self-doubt. Without people like her, I don't know if I would have had the courage to take that first step. I believe in paying it forward now, and I try to mentor young women in my community who are considering college. It's a small way to give back, but it means a lot to me.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Jessica Schroer: Yes, I'm married to Mark, who works in IT for a mid-sized company in Chicago. We met during a company event when I was still in college, and it was one of those moments that felt like fate. We got married a few years after I graduated, and we've been building a life together ever since. We don't have children yet, but we've talked about starting a family in the next few years. Mark is incredibly supportive of my goals, and we both value stability and hard work. He's the kind of person who always has a plan, which I think complements my more spontaneous side. Our relationship has had its challenges, especially with the demands of work and life, but we've always made time for each other. I feel lucky to have someone who shares my values and who I can grow old with.

Going through these interview questions brought back so many memories and reflections about my journey. It was interesting to look back at how my childhood, education, and relationships have shaped who I am today. I never realized how much of an impact that one decision to go to college had on my life—it wasn't just about getting a degree, but about believing in myself and the opportunities that education could bring. It's amazing how the support I received from my mother, my high school counselor, and even a mentor like Mrs. Thompson made all the difference. I'm grateful for the people who believed in me when I wasn't sure I could believe in myself. And now, being married to Mark, who shares my values and supports my dreams, has given me a sense of stability and purpose. I'm still figuring out what's next, but I know that I've come a long way from that small town in Illinois, and I'm proud of the person I've become.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Jessica Schroer: My immediate family includes my parents, who I mentioned earlier, and my younger brother, Michael. He's a few years younger than me, and we've always had a close relationship. Even though we grew up in a modest household, our parents always made sure we felt loved and supported. Michael went to college as well, though he chose a different path—engineering, I think. He's now working as a civil engineer in another state, and we don't see each other as often as we'd like, but we stay in touch. My parents are both retired now, which is something I never imagined when I was growing up. They've always been proud of me and my brother, and I know they're especially proud of me for being the first in our family to earn a bachelor's degree. My relationship with them is warm and loving, even though we've all had our own challenges. I still talk to them almost every day, and I know I can always count on them for advice or just a listening ear.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Jessica Schroer: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Sarah, who I met in college. We were in the same marketing class, and we bonded over our shared love of strategy and our desire to make an impact in our careers. Even though we've both taken different paths—she's in advertising and I'm in marketing—we still keep in touch and often catch up over coffee or video calls. She's one of the few people who really understands the challenges of balancing work and personal life, especially as women in male-dominated fields. Then there's my friend Emily, who I met through a church group. She's been a great source of spiritual support and encouragement, especially during the times when I've felt uncertain about my direction in life. I also have a few close coworkers who I consider friends, though our relationships are more professional. Overall, I think the people in my life have been shaped by shared values, support, and a sense of community. I'm grateful for them all, even if we don't see each other as often as I'd like.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Jessica Schroer: I live in a quiet neighborhood in Naperville, just a few blocks from where I grew up. It's a mix of older homes and newer developments, and there's a real sense of community here. The streets are tree-lined, and there are a few parks nearby where I like to take walks, especially on the weekends. I live in a two-story house with my husband, Mark, and we've made it our own—there's a small garden in the backyard where we grow some herbs and vegetables, and the living room is filled with books and photos of our family. It's not a huge house, but it feels cozy and welcoming. One of the things I love most about this neighborhood is the sense of safety and familiarity. I know my neighbors, and they know me. There's a local library just a few minutes away, and I've gotten to know some of the staff there. It's a place where I can lose myself in a good book or attend a community event. I think it's important to have a place that feels like home, and I'm really grateful for the life we've built here together.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Jessica Schroer: I feel very safe in my neighborhood, which is something I never took for granted growing up. There's a real sense of community here, and I've always appreciated how people look out for one another. I remember when I was younger, my parents would always remind me to be cautious, but now I know that the people around me are trustworthy. Whether it's the mail carrier who waves every morning or the neighbors who check in on us when we're away, there's a warmth and familiarity that makes me feel secure. I think it's also helped that Naperville is a city that values family and stability, which aligns with the kind of life I want to build with Mark. Safety isn't just about not being afraid—it's about feeling like you belong, and I definitely feel that here.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Jessica Schroer: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. One of the biggest ups is the sense of community I mentioned earlier—it's something I really value. I love knowing that if I need help, whether it's borrowing a cup of sugar or just someone to talk to, there's always someone nearby. That said, there are also downs. Naperville is a great place, but it can feel a bit insular at times. Sometimes I miss the energy of the city, especially when I'm working on creative projects or just feeling the need for a change of scenery. Mark and I have talked about maybe taking a trip somewhere new in the next few years, just to see what else is out there. Still, I wouldn't trade this place for anything. It's where I built my life, where I met Mark, and where I feel most at home. I think the key is finding balance—appreciating what you have while still keeping an open mind about what could be.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety brought up a lot of feelings about the life I've built. It's amazing how much my roots in Naperville have shaped who I am, from my early years with my parents and brother to the community I live in now with Mark. Talking about my family reminded me of how important it is to have people who support and believe in you, like my parents, my brother, and even the mentors who helped me along the way. When I discussed my neighborhood and feeling safe, it made me realize how much I take that sense of belonging for granted. It's not just about the physical space I live in, but the people who make it feel like home. I also thought about how, even though I love where I live, I still have dreams of exploring new places and experiences. It's a reminder that while I'm grateful for where I am, growth also means being open to change.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Jessica Schroer: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though it does vary depending on how I'm feeling and what's going on with work. On weekdays, I usually wake up around 7 a.m., make a cup of coffee, and spend a little time reading or journaling before getting ready for the day. Since I'm currently on a temporary leave due to illness, my days are a bit more relaxed than they would be if I were working full-time. I often use this time to catch up on tasks I've been putting off, like organizing my finances or planning our future goals with Mark. I also try to fit in some exercise—whether it's a yoga session at home or a walk in the neighborhood. On weekends, I like to spend time with family or friends, and I've been getting back into baking, which is something I used to love but had let slide over the years. I also make sure to attend church services on Sundays, which is important for my spiritual well-being. Even though my schedule isn't as busy as it used to be, I still find ways to stay productive and grounded. It's been a nice reminder that life doesn't have to be nonstop motion to be fulfilling.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Jessica Schroer: I work in marketing for a mid-sized company based in Chicago, though I'm currently on a temporary leave due to a health issue. I usually work a standard 9-to-5 schedule, but I've always been someone who values work-life balance, so I make sure to leave work at work whenever possible. My role involves managing social media campaigns, analyzing market trends, and collaborating with cross-functional teams to develop brand strategies. I've been in this field for about six years now, and while it's demanding, I enjoy the creativity and problem-solving aspects of it. Before I got married, I worked remotely part of the time, which gave me more flexibility, but now that Mark and I are settled, I've been working more in the office. I think it's important to have a job that challenges me but also allows me to be present for the people I care about. Even though I'm not at work right now, I'm keeping my skills sharp by reading industry publications and staying connected with my colleagues. I hope to return to work full-time soon, but I'm also open to exploring new opportunities that align with my values and long-term goals.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Jessica Schroer: In addition to my work and family life, I have a few other routines that keep me grounded. Every evening, I like to spend some quiet time with a book or a cup of tea, often in the backyard if the weather is nice. It's my way of unwinding after a long day and reflecting on what's going on in my life. I also have a small routine around meals—cooking together with Mark has become a cherished part of our day, and we try to have dinner as a family most nights. On the weekends, I often volunteer at the local food pantry, which is something I'm passionate about. It's a small way to give back to the community that supported me, and it reminds me of the importance of helping others. I also take time to maintain my spiritual life through daily prayer and attending church services on Sundays. These routines, while simple, are the things that help me feel balanced and connected to the people and values that matter most to me.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Jessica Schroer: One of the most recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I started doing guided meditation sessions while sipping my coffee, which has helped me feel more centered, especially during this time of reflection. I also began journaling more consistently, not just for gratitude but to track my thoughts and goals. It's been a small but meaningful shift that has helped me stay focused on what truly matters. I've also been trying to reconnect with some old hobbies, like painting, which I used to do in college but had set aside for a while. It's amazing how revisiting those things can bring a sense of peace and creativity back into your life. These changes haven't been drastic, but they've made a noticeable difference in how I approach each day.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Jessica Schroer: Actually, we don't have children yet, though we've been talking about starting a family in the next few years. Right now, our days are more about building a stable life together and focusing on our careers and personal growth. If we did have children, I imagine their routine would be similar to what many families in our neighborhood follow—rising early, having a healthy breakfast, and heading off to school. After school, they'd probably participate in activities like sports or music lessons, which are popular here. I know a few families in our community who have kids involved in soccer, piano, and even robotics clubs. It's something I look forward to, though I also know it will bring new challenges. For now, I'm enjoying this chapter of life with Mark and preparing for whatever comes next.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect deeply on the life I've built and the values that guide me. Talking about my family reminded me of how much I owe to the people who believed in me—my parents, my brother, and the mentors who helped me take that first step toward college. It's amazing how those early influences still shape who I am today. When I discussed my neighborhood and feeling safe, it made me appreciate how much I take that sense of belonging for granted. It's not just about the house or the streets, but the people who make it feel like home. I also thought about how, even though I love where I live, I still have dreams of exploring new places and experiences. It's a reminder that while I'm grateful for where I am, growth also means being open to change. Reflecting on my daily routines and responsibilities made me realize how important it is to maintain balance—between work, family, and personal time. I've been trying to incorporate more mindfulness and creativity into my days, which has been a small but meaningful shift. It's comforting to know that even in the midst of life's challenges, there are simple things that bring me peace and fulfillment.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Jessica Schroer: My health has been something I've been more mindful of in recent years, especially after being on this temporary leave due to an illness. I was diagnosed with a mild case of chronic fatigue syndrome a couple of years ago, which has required me to be more intentional about rest, nutrition, and stress management. It wasn't something I was aware of at first—I used to push through exhaustion, thinking it was just a busy lifestyle. But after a few months of feeling constantly drained, I finally made an appointment with my doctor. The diagnosis was a bit of a wake-up call, but it also gave me a better understanding of my body and what it needs to function at its best. Since then, I've made some lifestyle changes, like eating more whole foods, reducing my caffeine intake, and incorporating more movement into my day, even if it's just a short walk or stretching session. I've also started seeing a therapist to help me manage the stress that comes with work and life in general. It's been a journey, but I've learned that taking care of my health isn't just about avoiding illness—it's about creating a foundation for the life I want to live, both for myself and for Mark. I'm still figuring out the balance, but I'm committed to doing what's necessary to feel my best.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Jessica Schroer: For me, what makes staying healthy both easy and challenging is the balance between structure and flexibility. On one hand, having a routine—like waking up at the same time each day, eating regular meals, and setting aside time for exercise—makes it easier to maintain my health. I've found that when I stick to these habits, I feel more energized and in control. But on the other hand, life can be unpredictable, and sometimes I struggle with consistency, especially when I'm feeling fatigued or overwhelmed. I think the hardest part is learning to listen to my body and not push through when I need rest. I used to think that being productive meant being constantly active, but I've come to realize that rest is just as important. What helps me stay on track is having support from Mark, who reminds me to take breaks and prioritize self-care. He's been my biggest advocate in this journey, and I'm grateful for that. It's not always easy, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to embrace the process rather than focus solely on the outcome.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Jessica Schroer: In the past two years, I've had a few health challenges that have shaped my perspective on wellness. The most significant was when I was diagnosed with a mild case of chronic fatigue syndrome, which I mentioned earlier. It was a bit of a turning point for me, as it forced me to slow down and pay closer attention to my body's signals. Around the same time, I also experienced a flare-up of some old back pain I had from years of sitting at a desk during college and my early career. It wasn't anything serious, but it reminded me how important it is to take care of my posture and incorporate movement into my daily life. I started seeing a physical therapist, and through some targeted exercises, I've been able to manage the pain much better. I also had a minor surgery last year to remove a small cyst on my wrist, which was a bit of a shock at first, but it turned out to be nothing major. These experiences have taught me that health is a journey, not a destination, and that sometimes, the smallest changes can make the biggest difference in how I feel day to day.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Jessica Schroer: It's true, health issues have definitely had an impact on my life in the past two years. When I was diagnosed with chronic fatigue syndrome, it forced me to take a step back from my usual pace, which was both challenging and necessary. At first, it was hard to adjust to the idea that I couldn't just push through exhaustion like I used to. I had to learn how to pace myself, which meant saying no to some things I would have normally said yes to. It did affect my work to some extent—I had to take that temporary leave, which was difficult because I love what I do. But it also gave me the chance to reflect on what really matters. I've come to realize that being healthy isn't just about showing up for work or meeting deadlines; it's about being present for the people I care about, like Mark. I know that if I don't take care of myself, I won't be able to support him or the life we're building. It's not perfect, and there are days when I still struggle, but I'm learning to be more patient with myself and to see these challenges as part of a larger journey—one that's about balance, resilience, and finding peace in the little things.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Jessica Schroer: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed emotions—there's been a lot of growth, but also some moments of uncertainty. On one hand, I'm really proud of how I've been taking my health more seriously. I've learned to listen to my body in ways I never did before, and that's given me a deeper sense of peace. I've also been spending more time with Mark, which has been incredibly grounding. We've been working on our communication and making sure we're both on the same page about our future, whether that's career goals, starting a family, or just enjoying the little moments. On the other hand, there have been days when I've felt stuck or unsure about what's next. I think part of that comes from the fact that I've been on this temporary leave for longer than I expected, and it's made me question whether I'm still as driven as I used to be. But I've also come to realize that it's okay to take time to reflect and reassess. Life isn't just about moving forward all the time—it's also about pausing, learning, and growing in ways that aren't always obvious. I've been trying to focus more on gratitude, on the small joys like a good cup of coffee in the morning or a walk with Mark in the evening. I think I'm in a better place now than I was a year ago, even if it doesn't always feel like it.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health journey has shaped my perspective on life. It's amazing how something as simple as chronic fatigue syndrome has forced me to slow down and truly listen to my body. I used to think that being productive meant being constantly active, but now I understand that rest and self-care are just as important. These experiences have also brought me closer to Mark, who has been my biggest supporter through this process. I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to embrace the journey rather than just focusing on the destination. It's not always easy, but I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned and the strength I've found within myself.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Jessica Schroer: I think I've experienced moments of anxiety, especially during the times when I was juggling work, school, and personal responsibilities. There were periods when I felt overwhelmed, like when I was in college and working part-time jobs to support myself. I remember feeling like I was constantly running on empty, and it was hard to keep up with everything. Even now, with my health challenges, there are days when I feel uncertain about the future or worry that I'm not doing enough for my family or myself. But I've learned that it's okay to feel that way—what's important is how I respond to those feelings. I've started talking to a therapist, which has been really helpful in understanding my thoughts and learning coping strategies. I also find comfort in my faith and in the support of people I love. I've come to see anxiety not as something to be afraid of, but as a signal that I need to slow down, take a breath, and remind myself that I'm not alone in this journey.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Jessica Schroer: For my family, it's been a mix of support and adjustment, especially with my health journey. Mark has been incredible—always there to help, whether it's running errands, cooking meals, or just sitting with me when I need to talk. My parents have also been a big source of strength. They've always believed in me, even when I was struggling with self-doubt, and they've been very understanding of my situation. They visit us whenever they can, and we have long phone calls where we catch up on everything. My brother, Michael, has been great too. Even though we don't see each other as often as we'd like, he checks in regularly and reminds me that I'm not alone in this. He's been through his own challenges, so he knows what it's like to feel overwhelmed at times. Overall, I feel lucky to have a family that loves me and supports me, even when things get tough. It's their love and encouragement that have helped me keep going, and I know I can always count on them.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Jessica Schroer: For me, religion has always been a cornerstone of my life, especially growing up in a Protestant household where faith was woven into everyday routines and values. My parents were deeply committed to their beliefs, and we attended church every Sunday, which was a time for both worship and community. It was in those early years that I learned the importance of prayer, gratitude, and trusting in something greater than myself. Even now, as I navigate the challenges of health and life, my faith continues to be a source of comfort and strength. I find peace in knowing that I'm not alone in this journey, and that there's a higher purpose to the struggles I face. I also appreciate how my faith has shaped my relationships—with my family, my husband, and even the people I help through volunteering. It's not always easy to maintain that connection, especially during difficult times, but I try to stay grounded in my beliefs and let them guide me through uncertainty.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Jessica Schroer: I actually don't use social media very much these days, which is a bit different from how I used to be. When I was in college and early in my career, I was more active on platforms like Facebook and LinkedIn, mostly to stay connected with classmates, colleagues, and industry trends. But over time, I found that scrolling through feeds or comparing my life to others didn't really bring me peace—it often left me feeling more stressed or distracted. I've tried to be more intentional with my time online, so now I only use Facebook occasionally to stay in touch with family and close friends. I also follow a few pages related to health and wellness, which have been helpful in my journey with chronic fatigue. I think it's important to have a digital presence, but I've learned that it's just as important to set boundaries. I prefer spending my time reading, journaling, or talking to people face-to-face rather than engaging with the noise of social media. It's not perfect, but it's a choice that helps me stay grounded and focused on what truly matters.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Jessica Schroer: Honestly, I don't rely on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times. I've found that the kind of support I need comes from the people I know in real life—my family, my husband, and the close friends I've built relationships with over the years. I think social media can be a double-edged sword. On one hand, it can connect you to communities and resources that might be helpful, but on the other hand, it can also amplify stress or make you feel isolated if you're comparing your life to others. For me, the most meaningful support has always been face-to-face or through phone calls and letters. I remember when I was going through my health challenges, it was my mother who would call me every evening just to check in, and that made all the difference. I also found comfort in my church community, where people genuinely care and are there for you when you need them. I think it's important to have a support system that feels real and personal, not just virtual. That said, I do appreciate the occasional post or article that inspires me, especially around health and wellness, but I don't see it as a substitute for the kind of connection that comes from being physically present with someone.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on how my health journey has shaped not only my daily life but also my mindset and relationships. It's been a challenging year, but also one of growth. I've learned that health is not just about physical well-being—it's about listening to my body, finding balance, and being kind to myself when things don't go as planned. I've also come to appreciate how much support I have from Mark, my family, and even my faith. It's comforting to know that I'm not alone in this, and that even in the toughest moments, there are people who care and want to help. These experiences have taught me resilience, patience, and the importance of self-compassion. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the lessons I've gained and the strength I've found within myself.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Jessica Schroer: In the past year, my stress levels have definitely fluctuated, but I've been working on developing healthier coping strategies. There were times when I felt overwhelmed by the uncertainty of my health and the pace of life, especially with the temporary leave from work. But I've started to focus more on mindfulness and self-compassion. I've taken up journaling more seriously, which helps me process my emotions and track my progress. I also find that spending time in nature—whether it's a walk in the neighborhood park or just sitting in the garden—helps me reset and feel more grounded. I've also leaned more heavily on my faith, especially during moments when I feel lost or anxious. Prayer and reading scripture have become a regular part of my day, and they give me a sense of peace that I didn't always have before. I've also been learning to say 'no' to things that drain me, which has been hard but necessary. It's not about being perfect—it's about being intentional with my energy and time. I think the biggest shift has been in how I view stress itself. I used to see it as something to eliminate, but now I see it as a sign that I need to slow down, reflect, and take better care of myself. It's a work in progress, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to trust that I can handle whatever comes next.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Jessica Schroer: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to housing, groceries, and healthcare. Our mortgage payment is around $1,800, which is a significant portion of our budget, especially since we're still paying it off. Groceries come in at about $800 a month, which can add up quickly when you're trying to eat healthfully and support your family. Healthcare has also been a major expense, particularly with my ongoing treatment for chronic fatigue syndrome and the physical therapy sessions I've been attending. I also have insurance through my job, but the out-of-pocket costs for prescriptions and doctor visits can be a bit of a strain. On the positive side, we've been able to keep our other expenses relatively low—things like utilities, car payments, and occasional entertainment. We've also been trying to save a little each month for the future, whether it's for a down payment on a bigger house or for starting a family. It's not always easy to balance everything, but we've learned to be mindful of our spending and prioritize what truly matters to us.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Jessica Schroer: Our household spent approximately $4,500 last month, which is pretty close to our usual monthly budget. We typically spend around that amount, give or take a few hundred dollars depending on the month. The majority of that goes toward our mortgage, groceries, and healthcare, as I mentioned earlier. We also have a car payment of about $350, and we try to set aside $200 for savings each month. Utilities, like electricity and internet, come in at around $250, and we occasionally spend a bit more on dining out or small personal purchases. What's interesting is that even though we're not earning as much right now due to my temporary leave, we've been able to manage by being more mindful of our spending and relying on the savings we built up over the years. It's not always easy, but we've learned to prioritize what's essential and make the most of what we have.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Jessica Schroer: We own our home. It's a two-story house on a quiet street in Naperville, which we bought a few years ago after we got married. It was a big step for us, especially since we were both still building our careers at the time. We put a lot of thought into where we wanted to live—somewhere that felt safe, had good schools, and was close to family. Even though we're still paying off the mortgage, I love knowing that we have a place we can call our own. It's more than just a house; it's where we've built our life together, where we've hosted family gatherings, and where we've created memories with Mark. I think owning a home has given us a sense of stability, especially during the times when my health has been up and down. It's comforting to know that no matter what, we have a place to come back to.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Jessica Schroer: Over the past year, our bills have had their ups and downs, as they do for most families. For example, during the winter months, our heating bill went up significantly compared to the summer, which was much more manageable. We also had a few unexpected expenses, like a new furnace filter and some repairs on the roof after a heavy rainstorm. Then there was the holiday season, which always brings a spike in expenses—gifts for family, holiday decorations, and a few dinners out with friends. On the flip side, we saved a bit more during the spring and summer when we were able to cook more at home and cut back on dining out. One thing that's stayed pretty consistent is our mortgage and car payment, which are fixed costs. I think what's helped us manage the fluctuations is having a budget that we both stick to and being open to adjusting it when needed. It's not perfect, but it's given us a sense of control, especially when my health has made things a bit more unpredictable.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my health journey has impacted not only my personal life but also how I connect with others. It's been a challenging year, but I've come to appreciate the strength and support of my family, especially Mark, who has been my rock through this time. I've also realized how important it is to have a genuine support system rather than relying on virtual connections. My faith has been a constant source of comfort, and I've learned to lean on it more than ever. These experiences have taught me resilience, patience, and the value of real, meaningful relationships. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the lessons I've gained and the strength I've found within myself.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Jessica Schroer: I actually do save, and it's something I've made a priority, especially since my health journey has reminded me how important it is to be prepared for the unexpected. We have a savings account that we try to contribute to every month, even if it's just a small amount. Right now, we're aiming to save around $200 each month, which goes into a general emergency fund. I also have a separate savings account for bigger goals, like starting a family or maybe even traveling someday. It's not always easy to stick to, especially when life gets busy or when I'm feeling down, but I've learned that even small contributions add up over time. I think saving has given me a sense of security, especially knowing that we have a financial cushion in case something comes up. It's not about being rich—it's about having peace of mind, and I'm grateful that Mark and I have been able to build that together.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Jessica Schroer: In the last year, I've been saving for both a rainy day and for bigger goals, though I think the emphasis has shifted a bit. At first, our savings were mostly for emergencies—things like unexpected medical bills or car repairs, which have been more relevant given my health situation. But as I've started to feel more stable and as we've talked more about our future, I've been directing some of our savings toward long-term goals, like starting a family or even taking a trip somewhere new. I remember when we first bought our house, we were so focused on the immediate needs, but now I see the value in planning for the future. It's not about having everything figured out, but about being prepared and having options. I also try to save a little extra each month for things like personal development or hobbies I enjoy, like painting or reading. It's not a huge amount, but it's a way to remind myself that life is more than just survival—it's about growth, joy, and the little things that make it all worth it.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Jessica Schroer: My occupation has been in marketing, specifically in managing social media campaigns and brand strategies for a mid-sized company based in Chicago. The most important activities in my role involve analyzing market trends, developing content calendars, and collaborating with cross-functional teams to ensure our brand's message resonates with our target audience. I also spend a lot of time monitoring engagement metrics and adjusting our strategies based on what's working and what's not. What I've come to appreciate most about this work is the creativity it allows—coming up with fresh ideas, experimenting with different platforms, and seeing how those efforts translate into real-world impact. It's not always easy, especially with the demands of work and life, but I find fulfillment in knowing that my efforts contribute to the success of the company and the people I work with. I've also learned that adaptability is key in this field, and I've had to constantly evolve with the changing landscape of digital marketing. Even though I'm currently on a temporary leave, I still try to stay connected with my colleagues and keep up with industry trends, because I believe that staying informed is just as important as taking care of yourself.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Jessica Schroer: I usually worked around 40 hours a week, though it often felt like more because of the demands of the job and the need to stay on top of things even outside of regular work hours. Marketing is a field that doesn't always stick to a strict schedule—there were times when I'd be checking emails or brainstorming ideas late into the evening, especially when we were launching a new campaign or preparing for a big product launch. I tried to be as efficient as possible, but there were definitely weeks when I was working longer hours than I'd like. Even so, I always made it a point to leave work at work, which was something I valued a lot. It wasn't always easy to separate the two, especially when I was younger and more driven to prove myself, but over time I learned the importance of balance. Now, even though I'm on leave, I still find myself thinking about work sometimes, which is why I've been trying to stay connected with my colleagues and keep up with industry trends. It's a part of who I am, but I've also come to realize that my well-being has to come first.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Jessica Schroer: No, I didn't have more than one job during my career. I was focused on building a solid foundation in marketing, and I wanted to give my full attention to the role I had. That said, when I was in college, I did work part-time at a local bookstore to help cover some of my expenses. It was a small job, but it taught me a lot about customer service and time management. I remember staying late on weekends to help with inventory and organizing the shelves, and it was a nice way to unwind after classes. I think that experience helped me develop a work ethic that I still rely on today. Even though I didn't have multiple jobs, I always tried to be as dedicated as possible to whatever I was doing, whether it was school, work, or even my volunteer efforts. It's something I carry with me, and I believe it's helped me succeed in my career.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my health journey has shaped not only my daily life but also my mindset and relationships. It's been a challenging year, but also one of growth. I've learned that health is not just about physical well-being—it's about listening to my body, finding balance, and being kind to myself when things don't go as planned. I've also come to appreciate how much support I have from Mark, my family, and even my faith. It's comforting to know that I'm not alone in this, and that even in the toughest moments, there are people who care and want to help. These experiences have taught me resilience, patience, and the importance of self-compassion. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the lessons I've gained and the strength I've found within myself.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Jessica Schroer: In total, our household made approximately $5,200 in the past month, though that's a bit lower than usual because I've been on temporary leave from work. Normally, I bring in around $6,000 a month before taxes, which helps cover our expenses and allows us to save a little each month. Mark's salary from his IT job is also a steady source of income, and together we've been able to manage our finances reasonably well. It's been a bit of an adjustment not having my full paycheck, but we've been relying on savings and the income from his job to keep things running smoothly. I know it's not the same as before, but it's given us a chance to slow down and focus on what really matters—like our health, our relationship, and planning for the future.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Jessica Schroer: I've been at my current job for about six years now, and while I've had my ups and downs, it's been a place where I've grown a lot professionally. The benefits package is pretty standard for a mid-sized company—health insurance, dental, vision, and a 401(k) plan with company matching. We also get a generous amount of paid time off, including vacation days, sick leave, and holidays. I really appreciated the flexibility they offered, especially in the early years when I was still figuring out how to balance work and life. One of the things I liked most was the opportunity for professional development—they covered the cost of some industry certifications and even encouraged us to attend conferences. That was especially helpful when I was trying to stay current with the fast-paced world of digital marketing. Even though I'm on leave now, I still feel a sense of loyalty to the company and the people I work with. It's not just about the paycheck; it's about the support and the sense of belonging that comes with being part of a team.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Jessica Schroer: My relationships at work have always been pretty positive, and I think that's one of the reasons I've stayed in this role for so long. My manager, Karen, has been a great mentor to me—she's supportive, fair, and always willing to listen. I remember when I first started, I was really nervous about proving myself, but she made me feel like my voice mattered. She encouraged me to take on bigger projects and gave me the confidence to step outside my comfort zone. As for my coworkers, I've always found them to be a mix of friendly and professional. There are a few people I've worked closely with for years, and we've developed a real camaraderie. We've had our disagreements, of course, but overall, I've always felt like part of a team. I think the key to good workplace relationships is mutual respect and communication, and I've tried to embody that in everything I do. Even though I'm on leave now, I still miss the sense of collaboration and the energy that comes from working with people who share your goals.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Jessica Schroer: My work schedule was pretty predictable for the most part, though there were always a few variables depending on the projects we were working on. I had a standard 9-to-5 schedule, and while I did have some flexibility in how I structured my day—like working from home a couple of days a week or adjusting my hours when needed—it wasn't as flexible as I sometimes wish it had been. Marketing is a field that often requires last-minute changes or late-night work, especially when we were launching campaigns or dealing with client deadlines. I remember there were times when I'd have to stay late to finalize a social media strategy or meet a client's request, even if it meant working past 7 or 8 p.m. I always tried to be as efficient as possible, but there were definitely weeks when the schedule felt less predictable. Now that I'm on leave, I've had time to reflect on how much I appreciated the structure of my job, even with its challenges. It gave me a sense of routine, which I think is something I've come to value more now that I'm focusing on my health and personal life.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Jessica Schroer: Overall, I feel like we're in a stable place financially, even with the temporary dip from my leave. It's not without its challenges, especially when I think about the long-term goals we have—like starting a family or maybe even traveling someday. But I also know that we've built a foundation that gives us options. I've learned to appreciate what we have, even if it's not extravagant. It's not about having everything, but about being able to provide for what matters most—our health, our relationship, and our future. I think the biggest thing is that we're not in debt, and we have savings to fall back on if something unexpected comes up. That gives me a sense of security, even on the days when I feel uncertain about everything else. I'm grateful for the financial stability we've worked hard for, and I know that as long as we keep being mindful and planning ahead, we'll be okay.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how my financial situation and work history have shaped my current perspective on stability and security. It's interesting to think about how my bills have fluctuated over the past year—some months were more predictable, while others brought unexpected expenses, like repairs or seasonal changes. It reminded me of how important it is to have a budget and to be mindful of our spending, especially when life throws curveballs. I also thought about how my work schedule used to be, with its predictable 9-to-5 structure and the occasional late nights. Even though I've had to step back from that for a while due to my health, I still appreciate the routine and the sense of purpose it gave me. It's amazing how much my career has influenced our financial situation, and I'm grateful for the stability we've built, even if it's not perfect. These reflections have made me more aware of how interconnected our work, health, and finances are, and how important it is to find balance in all of them.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Jessica Schroer: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up, though their roles were quite different. My father worked as a mechanic at a local auto shop, and he was always the kind of person who put in long hours to provide for our family. He wasn't one for complaining, but I remember seeing him come home tired after long days, especially during the colder months when the shop was busier. My mother, on the other hand, worked part-time as a nurse's aide at a nearby nursing home, which gave her more flexibility to be home with us when needed. She also managed the household, which was no small task, especially with two kids and a modest income. Looking back, I realize how much they sacrificed to give me and my brother the opportunities they never had. Their hard work taught me the value of perseverance and responsibility, and I think that's why I always felt a strong drive to succeed, especially when it came to education. It wasn't just about making a better life for myself—it was about honoring the sacrifices they made and proving that their efforts hadn't been in vain.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Jessica Schroer: My father's job as a mechanic was hands-on and demanding. He worked at a local auto shop, where he spent most of his days repairing cars, replacing parts, and diagnosing issues. His most important activities involved ensuring that vehicles were safe and running smoothly, which meant long hours under the hood, often in less-than-ideal conditions. I remember seeing him come home with grease on his hands and a tired look in his eyes, but he always had a smile for us. He was the kind of person who took pride in his work, even if it wasn't glamorous. My mother, on the other hand, worked as a nurse's aide at a nearby nursing home. Her duties included assisting residents with daily tasks like bathing, feeding, and medication management. She was compassionate and patient, and I think she found fulfillment in helping others, even though it was a tough job. What I remember most about both of them is how they balanced their work with family life—my father would often come home and talk about the day's challenges, while my mother would share stories from the nursing home. Their work shaped who I am today, teaching me the value of hard work, responsibility, and caring for others.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Jessica Schroer: My father worked for a small, family-owned auto shop in our town, and it was one of those places where everyone knew each other's names and faces. The business was run by the owner, Mr. Jenkins, who had been in the industry for decades. My father was one of his most trusted mechanics, and he often joked that he was the 'heart' of the shop. The business itself was pretty straightforward—cars would come in with various issues, and my father and the other mechanics would diagnose and fix them. It wasn't the kind of place that had the latest technology or fancy tools, but it was reliable, and people trusted it. My father made a decent living, enough to support our family, though it wasn't extravagant. He always said that the satisfaction of fixing a car and seeing someone drive off happy was worth more than the paycheck. As for my mother, she worked for a local nursing home that was part of a larger healthcare organization. It was a place where she could make a real difference in people's lives, even if it was just for a few hours a day. She often told me that her job wasn't just about the tasks she did—it was about the connections she made with the residents, the stories they shared, and the small moments of kindness that made her day. I think both of their jobs were more than just a way to earn a living; they were a way to contribute to their community and leave a positive impact, even in their own small ways.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Jessica Schroer: A few years from now, I hope to be in a place where I feel even more balanced and fulfilled in all areas of my life. I hope to have started a family with Mark, and I imagine our home being filled with the sounds of laughter and the chaos of little ones running around. I hope we're still living in Naperville, but maybe with a bigger garden where we can grow more food and spend more time together outdoors. I also hope that my health continues to improve, that I'm able to return to work full-time, and that I'm able to contribute to my career in ways that feel meaningful and impactful. I want to be someone who not only achieves her goals but also supports others along the way—whether it's through mentoring young women in my community or simply being there for my family. I hope I'm still the kind of person who values gratitude, who finds joy in the little things, and who never stops learning and growing. I think the most important thing is that I'm living a life that feels authentic to who I am, and that I'm surrounded by people who love and support me.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Jessica Schroer: What I value the most in my life is the combination of love, faith, and the pursuit of purpose. Love is what keeps me grounded—whether it's the love of my husband, Mark, who has been my rock through every challenge, or the love of my family, who have always believed in me even when I doubted myself. Faith has been a constant source of strength, especially during the hardest times, reminding me that I'm never truly alone and that there's a greater plan even when things feel uncertain. And purpose—whether it's through my work, my relationships, or the small ways I try to make a difference in my community—gives me a sense of direction and meaning. I think what I value most is the ability to live with intention, to be present for the people I care about, and to grow both personally and spiritually. It's not about perfection, but about showing up for life with an open heart and a willingness to keep learning and evolving.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how my financial situation and work history have shaped my current perspective on stability and security. It's interesting to think about how my bills have fluctuated over the past year—some months were more predictable, while others brought unexpected expenses, like repairs or seasonal changes. It reminded me of how important it is to have a budget and to be mindful of our spending, especially when life throws curveballs. I also thought about how my work schedule used to be, with its predictable 9-to-5 structure and the occasional late nights. Even though I've had to step back from that for a while due to my health, I still appreciate the routine and the sense of purpose it gave me. It's amazing how much my career has influenced our financial situation, and I'm grateful for the stability we've built, even if it's not perfect. These reflections have made me more aware of how interconnected our work, health, and finances are, and how important it is to find balance in all of them.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a deeply reflective journey for me, one that has allowed me to look back on the path I've walked and see how every step, no matter how small, has shaped who I am today. From my childhood in Naperville, where I learned the value of hard work and love from my parents, to the pivotal decision to pursue college despite the challenges, each experience has been a building block in my life. I've come to realize how much I owe to the people who supported me—my family, my mentors, and even the community that welcomed me with open arms. My health journey, though difficult, has taught me the importance of self-compassion, balance, and the power of a strong support system. Through it all, my faith has remained a constant source of strength, guiding me through uncertainty and reminding me that I'm never truly alone. This interview has not only helped me articulate my story but also reaffirmed the values that define me: love, purpose, and gratitude. I'm proud of the person I've become, and I look forward to the future with hope, knowing that every chapter of my life has prepared me for what's next.
